metadata.case_name: Ramprasad v. State of Madhya Pradesh & Anr.

facts.text: Hetampal Singh, father of defendant No. 2, was a licence holder for Gird District in the then State of Gwalior for distribution of grain.

Hetampal Singh entered into an agreement with the appellant-plaintiff on October 14, 1942 (Ex. 1), appointing the appellant as his commission agent (adhatia) for supplying grain seed, with specific terms on interest, commission, possession of goods, expenses, and authority to supply.

In pursuance of the agreement, the appellant purchased considerable stock of grain and had in possession on January 29, 1943, 4039 maunds 35 seers 4 chhatacks of gram. According to the appellant, on that day Hetampal Singh owed him Rs. 19,228/9/6.
Possession of the stock was taken over by the State Government on January 29 and 30, 1949. The State Government paid the price of the said stock to Hetampal Singh.
Hetampal Singh had died before the suit was filed, so defendant No. 2 was impleaded as his legal representative.
Appellant filed suit claiming Rs. 30,699/1/3 against both defendants. Plaint was bald, did not set out right against the State.
Trial court decreed suit against both defendants for Rs. 22,634/4/- together with costs and interest from date of decree.
State of Madhya Pradesh (1st defendant) appealed against the decree. Second defendant did not appeal.
Plaintiff filed cross-objection claiming interest on principal amount from date of suit till decree.
High Court allowed State's appeal, set aside decree against it, but failed to pass any order on cross-objection. Judgment dated September 12, 1962 in First Appeal No. 9 of 1959.

Grain was removed by Government from possession of appellant without force or fraud; appellant handed over grain in response to communication from Controller of Foodgrains. At no stage did he tell Government he was pledgee.
Plaintiff informed Government that Hetampal Singh owed him about Rs. 20,000/-, but voluntarily parted with possession without reserving lien.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant was a pledgee of the goods under the agreement, entitling him to claim against the State.
Whether the appellant had a lien over the goods as commission agent enforceable against the State.
Whether the High Court erred in not deciding the cross-objection for interest.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant was a pledgee of the goods in question.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S. 172 read with S. 148 of Contract Act; Santi Sahu vs. Sheogulam Sahu

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant had a lien over the goods as commission agent for compensation and expenses.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 221 of Contract Act; Balmukund vs. Jagannath

petitioner_arguments.text: Entitled to interest on principal Rs. 19,228/6/- at 4 1/2% from date of suit till decree via cross-objection.

respondent_arguments.text: Agreement does not constitute pledge; goods not pledged.
No plea of lien in plaint; possession parted voluntarily without reservation of lien; no force or fraud.

court_reasoning.text: Agreement does not show goods pledged to plaintiff; plaintiff in possession to dispose per directions of Hetampal Singh. No plea or issue on pledge.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Santi Sahu case inapplicable as agreement materially different.

court_reasoning.text: No plea of lien in plaint; question of lien is mixed law and fact. Possession parted voluntarily without reserving lien; informed of debt but no lien reservation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Agent's lien under S.221 lost by parting possession without reservation; unclear conditions of licence.

court_reasoning.text: High Court failed to deal with cross-objection; trial court rejected interest claim without reasons; plaintiff entitled to interest.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plaintiff entitled to interest on Rs. 19,228/6/- at 4 1/2% p.a. from suit to decree.

holdings.text: Appellant not a pledgee of the goods.
Appellant had no enforceable lien against State due to lack of plea and voluntary parting of possession without reservation.
Plaintiff entitled to interest on principal Rs. 19,228/6/- at 4 1/2% per annum from date of suit till decree.

precedents_cited.relevance: Agreement there constituted pledge under S.172 r/w S.148 Contract Act; materially different here.
Rule laid down does not bear on facts here.
Lien lost by parting possession unless reserved or by fraud.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Pledge, agent's lien for commission, disbursements, services.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed against State of Madhya Pradesh; cross-objection allowed granting interest at 4 1/2% p.a. on Rs. 19,228/6/- from date of suit till decree.
outcome.relief_granted: Interest on Rs. 19,228/6/- at 4 1/2% per annum from date of suit till date of decree.

key_quotes.text: "The agreement entered into between the plaintiff and Hetampal Singh does not show that the goods in question had been pledged to the plaintiff."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The lien of an agent being a mere right to retain possession of the property subject thereto, is lost by parting with the possession of the goods unless... reserved expressly or impliedly his right of lien."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: English translation of agreement provided in full, detailing terms of commission agency.
key_quotes.speaker: court
